TopicTitle: How much ore is in one asteroid?

Articles.Content: I read from wiki that asteroids have limited amount of ore within. Now I have a very difficult rescue operation undeway and I'm wondering if bringing class A to C asteroid to Laythe orbit worth the trouble. So the question is, does anyone have figures about what amount of ore is contained in each asteroid class?

> 
> I read from wiki that asteroids have limited amount of ore within. Now I have a very difficult rescue operation undeway and I'm wondering if bringing class A to C asteroid to Laythe orbit worth the trouble. So the question is, does anyone have figures about what amount of ore is contained in each asteroid class?

Roughly 80-90% of the asteroid mass. 10 kg equal to one unit of ore. So a 100 tons asteroid will yield some 9,000 ore, which equals to a large MK3 liquid fuel tank.

They just aren't worth it, which is a pity, as I was looking forward to use them as orbital refueling stations.

> 
> They just aren't worth it, which is a pity, as I was looking forward to use them as orbital refueling stations.

What were you expecting tho 100t asteroid turning into 100t fuel? In real life tar sands(Oil sands) gives %0.03 oil after the sand and dirt is removed and refined. Lets assume that in asteroids you are looking for oxygen and hydrogen to turn into fuel since they are the easiest kind of materials you can find as oxydizer and liquid fuel. This is giving you %1 turn rate atleast. I could understand if we had comets in ksp and mining them could provide maybe %90 fuel since they are generally made of ice.
